text:
Hey hey :wave:  Question: how to you measure the success of your LinkedIn ads that promote content, specifically a podcast?

Context: We’re launching LinkedIn ads to promote our podcast. My boss is pushing for a written down strategy to specify the metrics and how we’ll know if the ads have been a success. I plan to direct the LinkedIn ads to our podcast webpages that include the YouTube version and links to Spotify and Apple Podcasts (but let me know if you think they should direct to YouTube instead!). Other than traffic landing on the website from the LinkedIn ads, how would you go about defining the success of these ads? :thinking_face:

Any advice much appreciated :pray:

elements.text: Hey hey

Question: how to you measure the success of your LinkedIn ads that promote content, specifically a podcast?

Context: We’re launching LinkedIn ads to promote our podcast. My boss is pushing for a written down strategy to specify the metrics and how we’ll know if the ads have been a success. I plan to direct the LinkedIn ads to our podcast webpages that include the YouTube version and links to Spotify and Apple Podcasts (but let me know if you think they should direct to YouTube instead!). Other than traffic landing on the website from the LinkedIn ads, how would you go about defining the success of these ads?
Any advice much appreciated

text: We thought about promoting some episodes and not others to see if those we promoted performed better - but I’m conscious that could be misleading as episodes with different themes perform different anyway…

elements.text: We thought about promoting some episodes and not others to see if those we promoted performed better - but I’m conscious that could be misleading as episodes with different themes perform different anyway…

text: I’m going through this right now, <@U02ANC57AAY>. Going to a “hub” is best. It sounds like it’s not a direct customer journey for you, so don't over-promise. (You can lead a horse to water….) I would suggest a combination of CTR for the paid ads and referral traffic if you can get that separately from your web team (how many of the people going to the page are through your efforts). Another is CPC to show how effective the cost of your efforts are vs advertising in a diff way. See if you can get stats from the project manager on the other channels cpc. I would focus on strategy and customer journey and not a “whack-a-mole” of on and off ads because there are too many factors in why something performed better. Better to be consistent and try A/B/C testing than “2 ads, 0 ads, 1 ad, 0 ads, etc.” Does that help?

I would focus on strategy and customer journey and not a “whack-a-mole” of on and off ads because there are too many factors in why something performed better. Better to be consistent and try A/B/C testing than “2 ads, 0 ads, 1 ad, 0 ads, etc.” Does that help?

text: Chiming in here as well to confirm what others have said. Really depends on the audience and topic, but ~30% show rate is typical for your average webinar (in my experience). Different story as your webinar scales - you’ll typically see higher overall registrations but a lower show rate %. Could also depend on your promotion/reminder mix.

text: personally, I love gated content. I download them all the time. I like that they come to me via ads and are visual rather than just text, I like that they have everything I need to know about a subject instead of forcing me to click through various posts, and I like that i can save them and refer to them later in my drive instead of keeping 100 tabs open lol.

text: Going against the norm here, but I am a big fan of ungated content. We rarely gate pure written content. We see this as a way to educate our audience, build trust, and pull in organic traffic. We’ve also found the quality of folks that come in via a piece of content aren’t necessarily ready to be marketed to yet. What we do gate is super robust (like an annual data-driven report or survey that was a heavy lift) or video/event content (like webinars). We often pair these gated assets with an ungated written component (ex: a webinar recap blog with highlights and the full episode is gated). It’s a fine line to walk, and I realize that many teams are under pressure to deliver MQLs, that’s just my POV. From my own experience, I often DO submit my email to download something I’m interested in but then I just unsubscribe as soon as I get the first marketing email from the company :woman-shrugging:

elements.text: Going against the norm here, but I am a big fan of ungated content. We rarely gate pure written content. We’ve also found the quality of folks that come in via a piece of content aren’t necessarily ready to be marketed to yet. What we do gate is super robust (like an annual data-driven report or survey that was a heavy lift) or video/event content (like webinars). We often pair these gated assets with an ungated written component (ex: a webinar recap blog with highlights and the full episode is gated). It’s a fine line to walk, and I realize that many teams are under pressure to deliver MQLs, that’s just my POV. From my own experience, I often DO submit my email to download something I’m interested in but then I just unsubscribe as soon as I get the first marketing email from the company

text: Hi Steph, I think your goal might depend on the type of ad you’re running. Assuming an awareness-style video ad, the CTR and on-page engagement could be good indicators (are these folks watching/listening to an episode or two? Are they clicking on subscription links? Etc.). Another take could be to run remarketing on folks that did visit the page in a meaningful way to nudge them to actually subscribe. Subscriber growth would be your metric there. And, on a softer level, if paid is a large investment, an increase in search volume for the show could be a lagging indicator that the investment is working. Also, be sure to convey quality over quantity!

elements.text: Hi Steph, I think your goal might depend on the type of ad you’re running. Assuming an awareness-style video ad, the CTR and on-page engagement could be good indicators (are these folks watching/listening to an episode or two? Are they clicking on subscription links? Etc.). Another take could be to run remarketing on folks that did visit the page in a meaningful way to nudge them to actually subscribe. Subscriber growth would be your metric there. And, on a softer level, if paid is a large investment, an increase in search volume for the show could be a lagging indicator that the investment is working. Also, be sure to convey quality over quantity!

text: How do y’all decide to organize a content hub when there are seemingly endless ways to organize it and none of them seem quite right? lol. Usually that organization makes itself super clear to me immediately, but for this one I feel lost in a swamp. Anyone have any tips or frameworks?

elements.text: How do y’all decide to organize a content hub when there are seemingly endless ways to organize it and none of them seem quite right? lol. Usually that organization makes itself super clear to me immediately, but for this one I feel lost in a swamp. Anyone have any tips or frameworks?

text: When you say _organize_, do you mean what topics to include, what order to include them in, what subtopics should be discussed in which topic, how to design it from a UX perspective, or?

elements.text: When you say
organize
, do you mean what topics to include, what order to include them in, what subtopics should be discussed in which topic, how to design it from a UX perspective, or?

text: I have a good idea of the topics to cover, it’s more about how to create the buckets to organize the topics, because there’s gonna be a lot of content so it needs to be like a Hub homepage > Category 1 > multiple articles thing, and i’m having a hell of a time determining what the categories could be because there are a ton of different ways to organize the topics. Does that make sense?

elements.text: I have a good idea of the topics to cover, it’s more about how to create the buckets to organize the topics, because there’s gonna be a lot of content so it needs to be like a Hub homepage > Category 1 > multiple articles thing, and i’m having a hell of a time determining what the categories could be because there are a ton of different ways to organize the topics. Does that make sense?

text: It’s essentially like a House Efficiency 101 hub that’ll go into every way to make your home more efficient/green/lower energy bills/etc. But there’s a lot of overlap between topics so I can’t pull out a useful way to group them that would be really clear to people

elements.text: It’s essentially like a House Efficiency 101 hub that’ll go into every way to make your home more efficient/green/lower energy bills/etc. But there’s a lot of overlap between topics so I can’t pull out a useful way to group them that would be really clear to people

text:
Yep 100%. You can have hubs within hubs. We built an algorithm to help us understand how we should organize them, the tricky part is how to balance that with UX (what your audience actually cares about). Our approach was to take all of the topics, compare the SERPs for each one and calculate the degree of overlap between them and plot that using a graph database, that shows us how to group things.

If I were you, I would just Google the topics, look at the pages ranking and the _types_ of titles you see Google displaying. Drop the key themes in each title into a sheet, then do some qualitative coding on them to begin to group them together thematically. That’ll help you understand how they relate to one another.

As far as order goes (chronologically), when in doubt, I do two things:

1. Go to Wikipedia and see how they organize things.
2. Put together some ideas, then ask customers (provides tons of useful insights that you can repurpose into the actual content itself as well).

But wiki is a good idea. And yeah, I think I just need to keep pushing forward on the overall topics list and just keep banging my head against the wall re: organization until it falls in place

text: <@U0113AV4895> overlapping info is fine. Visitors won't read every piece of your hub in one sitting. Repetition is part of the education process and the spirit of a great hub. Here's my recommendation: start with broad research on topics and keywords. Get a big list going somewhere. Then start grouping things by similar categories and concepts. After that, answer the question: "how do I unpack this info in a way that makes it easy to digest and learn?" i.e., how can you guide a visitor from a to b then to b to c and so on. What you'll find is the structure slowly starts to reveal itself as you work through this process.

text:
I don't recommend this a lot, but would there be a benefit to have two different ways to organize content in this case? So maybe primary hubs would be something like "smart home," "energy efficient appliances," etc. and then you can tag them based on home area (kitchen, bedroom, etc.) so that users can view content in either way?

I say that with zero research, and I agree with Skyler about the way to typically do the research... but if there's not much to go on from existing content structure, that at least feels like a way to make sure users can sort content by the way they see relevancy. :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2:

text:
We do a combination of what’s been mentioned. Here’s a quick overview..  

We start with the clients goals and make sure they know what the implications of those are down to how the posts are chosen. For example, we don’t let them say their goals are more for brand focused content then want keyword metrics on those. Your goals must align with the content and metrics. 

Then we choose the percentage of content we produce each month that fits those goals. Eg. 50% keyword focused, 50% brand focused content. This informs how we source the content. 

Then we break it down by category and percentages of the content each month that goes into each category. That helps us know exactly what we’re talking about. Note, this can change monthly, especially for seasonal brands. We plan it out by quarter in a quarterly planning session. 

Then we evaluate the specific posts with a decision matrix to ensure it the criteria all the way up to the main goals (you can see we really hammer those home :smile:) Here’s a screenshot of some of those criteria: <https://share.getcloudapp.com/6quEAQOd>

attachments.fallback: Created with CloudApp Photo: Fluxe Blog Post Idea Validation Checklist #Process - Google Docs 2022-02-11 at 12.18.05 PM
attachments.title: Fluxe Blog Post Idea Validation Checklist #Process - Google Docs 2022-02-11 at 12.18.05 PM

text:
Here's how we organized ours <https://ghost.org/resources>

It's essentially chronological (get started > start publishing > grow an audience > build a business). The complexity of our posts also change depending on which bucket they fall into (e.g., beginner posts use more images, simple examples; while business posts use greater detail and advanced examples that rely on more contextual knowledge).

So far we'd had a very positive response from our audience. They can basically make camp in one section until they're ready to "graduate" into the next.

attachments.fallback: Ghost Newsletter: Ghost Resources — Stories & Ideas About Indie Publishing
attachments.text: A library of resources to help you share content, grow your audience, and build an independent subscription business in the creator economy!
attachments.title: Ghost Resources — Stories & Ideas About Indie Publishing
